newsitem.title: CHINA: FORECAST - Shanghai state debt prices see no change.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Shanghai state debt prices see no change.

text.p: Chinese state debt spot contracts on the Shanghai stock exchange are not expected to move much over the next month with high yields offset by a bull run on the domestic A share markets, analysts said on Tuesday.
The seven listed spot contracts now have an average yield of around 10 percent per year, much higher than the 7.47 percent rate for one-year bank deposits.
But the A share bull run is sucking money out of the state debt spot market, they said. In the past six weeks alone, Shanghai's A share index has surged 23.5 percent.
In addition, an increasing number of new A share issues has attracted speculative funds away from the spot debt market, the analysts said.

"The A share markets have been very active in the past few weeks, and that has caused a lot of speculative funds to leave the state debt spot market," one state debt trader said. "Heavy new A share issues have made liquidity even tighter."
"But the yields of the existing countracts are high and this will prevent them from falling sharply," he added.

"Market fundamentals are unlikely to change much in the next month on either the state debt or the stock markets," said a securities investment analyst. "Prices of the state debt contracts will see little change as a result."

The Shanghai exchange accounts for over 95 percent of state debt trading in China and its prices quotations have a decisive impact on trading in other markets including on the Shenzhen stock exchange and the Wuhan Securities Trading Centre.

Since its establishment in 1992, the spot debt market has grown to become a barometer of China's monetary policy with prices surging or plunging on major policy changes. The contracts are nearly exclusively traded by institutions.
"No fresh-market moving factors are seen in the near future, which is another reason for the contracts to move narrowly in the next month," the investment analyst said.

At the close of business on Tuesday, the market's most active 10-year bond that matures in June 2006, a market barometer, rose to 117.4 yuan ($14.14) from 116.29 yuan on a technical rebound after a few weeks of falls.

"The 10-year bond is likely to move in a narrow range of 115 to 118 yuan in the next month," said a second state debt trader. "Trading in the market is expected to be very dull if the A share markets continue their bull run."
But a lull on the secondary debt market will not affect China's record state debt issue this year, partly because Chinese retail investors focus almost exclusively on new issues, the analysts said.

"Most investors have no time to trade on the secondary market and are very wary of the risks there," said one state debt analyst. "But they will continue to buy state debt as it is issued. The good sales on the primary market so far this year prove that."
China plans to issue a record 248.596 billion yuan worth in state debt in 1997, the Finance Ministry has announced.
In contrast to the spot market, analysts said Shanghai's state debt repurchase market will continue to boom next month.

The repo market, whose rate movements are effectively governed by the performance of the A share markets, has been active in the past few weeks with interest rates for repo papers staying at high levels.
Analysts said they believed the annual rates for the most active seven-day contract would continue to move around a high 16 percent next month.
